Author: September#5047
Content: Hi, I've made sure to re-check my code with the tutorial in mario0, but I can't seem to figure out why my screen has this odd lines. Is this a hardware issue?

Author: kappilino#9875
Content: Have the same issue. But it occures only when the the map moves.

Author: kappilino#9875
Content: No, now after programming the translate function it occures also on the not animated version. Even if i comment all the animation functionality out. Very weird.

Author: kappilino#9875
Content: OK...i have found the issue. The initialization of the map object must be after the setDefaultFilter function. In mario0 the the initialization is before it. I do not know why it works there, but not in our versions.

Author: kappilino#9875
Content:
Next problem in mario3. If I generate the world in the map class, in the while function creates always a gap on the last position on the right of the map. Because the condition x < self.mapWidth is false there. 
A second problem, the else clause at the end of the loop, which creates a 2 tile gap, is theoretically capable of creating an endless gap. Because there is no condition that prevent to generate one 2-tile-gap after a 2-tile-gap.

Author: asmat#3174
Content:
my code of Map.lua so far as in mario0
Map = Class{}

TILE_BRICK = 1
TILE_EMPTY = 4

function Map:init()
    self.spritesheet = love.graphics.newImage('graphics/spritesheet.png')
    self.tileWidth = 16
    self.tileHeight = 16
    self.mapWidth = 30
    self.mapHeight = 28
    self.tiles{}

    self.tileSprites = generateQuads(self.spritesheet, self.tileWidth, self.tileHeight)

    -- filling the map with empty tiles
    for y = 1, self.mapHeight / 2 do
        for x = 1, self.mapWidth do
            self:setTile(x, y, TILE_EMPTY)
        end
    end

    -- starts halfway down the map, populates with bricks
    for y = self.mapHeight/2, self.mapHeight do
        for x = 1, self.mapWidth do
            self:setTile(x, y, TILE_BRICK)
        end
    end
end

function Map:setTile(x, y, tile)
    self.tiles[(y - 1) * self.mapWidth + x] = tile
end

function Map:getTile(x, y)
    return  self.tiles[(y - 1) * self.mapWidth + x]
end

function Map:update(dt)
    
end

function Map:render()
    for y = 1, self.mapHeight do
        for x = 1, self.mapWidth do
            love.graphics.draw(self.spritesheet, self.tileSprites[self:getTile(x, y)], (x - 1) * self.tileWidth, (y - 1) * self.tileHeight)
        end
    end
end

Author: Vince#6486
Content:
> Hi, I've made sure to re-check my code with the tutorial in mario0, but I can't seem to figure out why my screen has this odd lines. Is this a hardware issue?
@September He addresses this issue in the videos actually, it's caused by the frames loading at a fractional value, he (and you) can solve it using the math.floor function in the render call

Author: Vince#6486
Content: @asmat if you get an error code that says 'nil value' it means that the variable you are calling hasn't been initialised

Author: Vince#6486
Content: Just from reading the error message, I think you're calling the variable 'tiles' when you should be calling 'tile'

Author: Vince#6486
Content: my mistake, you've got a typo in line 12

Author: Vince#6486
Content: you put 'self.tiles{}' when it should be 'self.tiles = {}'

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: Fun fact, on 144hz monitors, math.floor(self.camX/Y + SCROLL_SPEED * dt) is always 0

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: I had to swap to math.ceil to get the way he coded it to work

Author: Napoopan Totallatot, Worm King#3698
Content: (if SCROLL_SPEED is less than something like a few hundred)
